sources.why: Miami-Dade County commercial wastewater system requirements and permitting

linkable_points: Grease traps intercept fats, oils, greases (FOG), and solid food waste before entering municipal wastewater system, functioning as containment boxes separating materials by density to prevent pipe blockages
Grease trap installation for restaurants in Miami-Dade typically costs $2,000-$15,000 depending on trap size, material type, installation location, site conditions, and complexity
Restaurants produce substantially more FOG than residential kitchens due to continuous food preparation requiring proper grease interception to prevent sewer backups and environmental pollution

Most local governments including Miami-Dade legally require restaurants to maintain grease traps to protect municipal sewer systems, with health department inspections verifying proper installation and function

Grease traps are manufactured from stainless steel, plastics, concrete, or cast iron with capacity ranging from 35 liters for small operations to 45,000+ liters for large facilities, positioned above or below ground

Regular cleaning schedules are essential to prevent grease buildup, clogs, overflows, and system failures, with proper maintenance protecting communities from health hazards and helping restaurants avoid fines

Miami-Dade County requires permits for grease trap installation, professional installation by licensed contractors, compliance with commercial wastewater regulations, and regular maintenance documentation

Professional installation ensures compliance with Miami-Dade County regulations, proper trap sizing based on kitchen flow rates, correct positioning, environmental protection, and long-term reliability
